segment.source: In XAML markup, specifies a null value for a property.
segment.target: In XAML markup, specifies a null value for a property.

segment.source: {x:Null} markup extension
segment.target: {x:Null} markup extension

segment.source: {x:Null} markup extension
segment.target: {x:Null} markup extension

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: In XAML markup, specifies a null value for a property.
segment.target: In XAML markup, specifies a null value for a property.

segment.source: XAML attribute usage
segment.target: XAML attribute usage

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: null is the null reference keyword for C# and C++.
segment.target: null is the null reference keyword for C# and C++.

segment.source: The Microsoft Visual Basic keyword for a null reference is Nothing.
segment.target: The Microsoft Visual Basic keyword for a null reference is Nothing.

segment.source: The initial default value can vary between dependency properties, and it is not necessarily null.
segment.target: The initial default value can vary between dependency properties, and it is not necessarily null.

segment.source: Further, many dependency properties will not accept null as a value (whether through markup or code) due to their internal implementation.
segment.target: Further, many dependency properties will not accept null as a value (whether through markup or code) due to their internal implementation.

segment.source: In such cases, setting a XAML attribute value with {x:Null} can result in a parser exception.
segment.target: In such cases, setting a XAML attribute value with {x:Null} can result in a parser exception.

segment.source: Some Windows Runtime types are nullable.
segment.target: Some Windows Runtime types are nullable.

segment.source: In cases where a nullable type does not already have null as the default, you could use {x:Null} in XAML to set to the null value.
segment.target: In cases where a nullable type does not already have null as the default, you could use {x:Null} in XAML to set to the null value.

segment.source: If using Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX), nullable types are represented as Platform::IBox.
segment.target: If using Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX), nullable types are represented as Platform::IBox.

segment.source: If using Microsoft .NET languages, nullable types are represented as Nullable.
segment.target: If using Microsoft .NET languages, nullable types are represented as Nullable.

segment.target: Related topics
